record.text:
The Telegraph going after the Quakers because the Quakers won't be assholes to trans people.

That opening paragraph by Daniel Martin is lol. It's Helen Joyce doing the accusing.

images.alt:
Quakers refuse to ban trans women from female lavatories
The Daily Telegraph27 May 2025By Daniel Martin Deputy political editor
QUAKERS have been accused of “destroying” their reputation as pioneers on women’s rights by refusing to provide female-only lavatories.

The group said its lavatories in Britain would remain “trans inclusive” despite the ruling by the Supreme Court that the word “sex” in the Equality Act refers to biological sex and not gender identity.

It said it was not desirable to monitor who uses its facilities, adding: “We can- not guarantee any shared space as exclusive for one group of people.”

The Quakers have gained a reputa- tion for their progressive attitude towards women, having allowed them to preach as early as the 17th century. But Helen Joyce, the director of advocacy at Sex Matters, a women’s rights group, said they appeared to have abandoned that legacy by adopting “textbook trans activism”.

“Early Quakers were famously supportive of women’s rights – they would surely be shocked and ashamed if they could see the destruction of that proud legacy,” she added. #TransAgendaClips

ACIP may remove universal hep B birth dose for healthy infants with HBsAg-negative moms. Current vaccine cuts perinatal infections by 70%-90%, preventing ~625 cases/year. Removal risks +8%-76% infections.🍼🦠

#idsky

external.description:
In September 2025, the newly formed Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) revisited its long-standing recommendation for the universal hepatitis B vaccine birth dose: its safety, efficacy, and public health impact. On the agenda for the December 4-5 ACIP meeting is a discussion of and a possible vote to eliminate the recommendation for a birth dose of hepatitis B vaccine (ie, within 24 hours of birth) for healthy infants born to mothers with a negative hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) result during pregnancy. The anticipated vote will recommend no hepatitis B vaccination for these infants for at least 1 month. Here, we review the history of this policy and the risks of rescinding it, and estimate the number of perinatal infections that may occur under revised guidelines.















































 
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a highly infectious and environmentally resilient double-stranded DNA virus, maintaining infectiousness on surfaces for up to 1 week. In the 1980s, there was an estimated peak of 1.2 million people in the US with chronic hepatitis B. Demonstrative of progress in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of HBV infections, the number of cases in the US has fallen to 660 000—approximately half of whom are still unaware of their infection—with prevalence more concentrated in Asian and Black communities.1 The vast majority of the morbidity, mortality, and health care costs incurred by HBV infections are associated with chronic infection, primarily related to cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.2 The risk of developing chronic HBV infection depends heavily on age at the time of acquisition; only 20% to 30% of those infected after age 6 develop chronic disease, compared with 70% to 90% of those infected earlier in childhood. Among infants with perinatally acquired chronic HBV infection who are untreated, 25% die prematurely. Thus, elimination of perinatal and childhood infection is a critical target of HBV prevention efforts. 
The HBsAg test first became available in 1969 and detects acute and chronic HBV infection.3 In 1984, prenatal HBsAg screening was targeted to “high-risk” women, and hepatitis B vaccination was recommended to be administered soon after birth to infants born to women who were HBsAg positive. This risk-based approach failed to identify HBV infections and as such, in 1988, both the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommended universal HBsAg testing in pregnancy. Despite clear guidance from professional societies, between 50 and 100 annual reported cases of acute HBV infection in infants remained for the next decade in the US. These infections reflected “leakage” across the continuum of maternal-infant care, spanning pregnancy, delivery, and the postnatal period. That leakage prompted further recommendations—first introduced in 1991—for routine administration of hepatitis B vaccine to all newborns before hospital discharge. Continued and successful efforts to close the gaps of screening and newborn immunoprophylaxis resulted in strengthening and reaffirmation of ACIP universal birth dose vaccination recommendations in both 2005 and 2018.4 
The standard hepatitis B vaccine—a 3-dose series, given at 0 (birth), 1, and 6 months—has been rigorously studied and continuously monitored since licensure; the birth dose recommendation was developed on the foundation of extensive evidence demonstrating its safety and efficacy when administered shortly after birth.5 Although no safety signals were ever identified,6 thimerosal was removed from the vaccine in the US in 1999; an action taken, after extensive review, to strengthen public confidence in the vaccine. Since then, randomized trials, safety monitoring, and large cohort studies have consistently confirmed the vaccine’s safety. There is no evidence of increased risk for any adverse events, including serious adverse events, when the hepatitis B vaccine is given shortly after birth compared with administration at 1 month of age or later. 
Today, among all pregnant women in the US, approximately 0.5% test positive for HBsAg and, in 2021, an estimated 17 827 infants were born to such mothers.7 Under these conditions, hepatitis B vaccine administered at birth reduces perinatal transmission by approximately 70% and, when paired with hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG), prevents more than 90% of perinatal infections. Meta-analyses suggest that vaccination in infancy confers long-term protection, at least 90% at 17 years; further studies demonstrate no decrease in the durability of this protection if the series is initiated within 7 days vs at 4 weeks after birth.8 Given the remarkable efficacy of the vaccine, reported cases of perinatal hepatitis B infection have ranged in the tens of cases annually for the past decade, though this is likely an underestimate of the true HBV infection burden due to shortfalls in screening, follow-up, and reporting. Even so, acute HBV infection among infants and young children has declined to exceptionally low levels. 
Perinatal infections arise through 3 main pathways (Figure). First, some women with a true positive HBsAg test result do not receive guideline-concordant management or timely immunoprophylaxis of their infant because of systemic, logistical, or access failures (dark blue bars). Second, some mothers do not receive HBsAg screening during pregnancy so their HBV status is unknown (light blue bars). Although guidelines recommend vaccinating these infants, only about 80% of these infants receive this recommended vaccine.9 Finally, some mothers test negative during pregnancy but have HBV infection at delivery, either because of a false-negative result or because they acquire acute HBV while pregnant but after the screening test (orange bars). Infants in this last group would lose protection under a revised policy to remove the birth dose for infants born to mothers with an HBsAg-negative result. 

Figure.  Estimated Number of Perinatal HBV Infections Annually in the US Under Various Hepatitis B Birth Dose Recommendations View LargeDownload   (opens in new tab)Go to Figure in ArticleThe figure represents the subset of mothers with acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. All estimates were calculated using the following default values: 3 591 328 annual births in the US; 0.38% prevalence of HBV infection in pregnant women; 85.4% HBsAg screening in pregnancy; 2% HBsAg false-negative rate (1 − sensitivity); 35.7% perinatal transmission rate of HBV in the absence of vaccine or hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG); and 94% vaccine effectiveness for hepatitis B vaccine birth dose + HBIG, 75% vaccine effectiveness for hepatitis B vaccine birth dose alone.4 Among HBsAg-positive women, 96% of infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers receive HBIG plus vaccination at birth; 3% receive neither vaccine nor HBIG. Among women with false HBsAg-negative and HBsAg-unknown status, 80% receive the vaccine at childbirth.9 HBsAg-negative accounts for false-negative HBsAg results during pregnancy and newly acquired HBV infection after a prior negative HBsAg result. 
Under the current standard of care (universal hepatitis B birth dose), we project 625 perinatal HBV infections annually.5  Eliminating the birth dose for infants of HBsAg-negative mothers—as proposed—would raise the number of cases to 674, an 8% increase (Figure, red circle). Restricting the birth dose only to infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers would raise perinatal HBV cases to 1101—an additional 63%, or a 76% increase from current (Figure, red box). Our projected transmissions are higher than those reported to the CDC, figures known to underestimate the true burden of disease due to underreporting, undiagnosed infections, and possible model bias.5,10 Still, the model is useful for assessing how changes to birth dose recommendations affect expected perinatal transmission. The model likely underestimates the increase that would follow abandonment of universal birth dose policy because it does not account for rising vaccine hesitancy, the birth dose’s protection against postnatal HBV transmission in infancy, or reduced adherence when the first dose is delayed until 1 month of age. 
We applaud the periodic revisiting of routine recommendations as new data emerge and with changes in the epidemiology of disease. In that context, updated studies on the hepatitis B birth dose strengthen prior findings of its remarkable safety and impressive efficacy, documenting a profound decline in HBV infections among infants and children in the US. Delaying the first hepatitis B vaccine dose beyond the newborn period introduces risks that have lifelong detrimental consequences and no measurable health benefit. Universal birth dose recommendations provide a critical safety net for infants and remain a cornerstone of the US strategy to eliminate hepatitis B.
















Back to top

                                Article Information
                            

Corresponding Author: Rochelle Walensky, MD, MPH, Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02114 (Rochelle.Walensky.MD@gmail.com).Published Online: December 3, 2025. doi:10.1001/jama.2025.24996Conflict of Interest Disclosures: Dr Ulrich reported that the Vaccine Integrity Project is supported by an unrestricted gift from Alumbra Innovations Foundation to the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota. Dr Walensky reported receiving fees from Madryn Asset Management for serving as a senior policy advisor, Consonance Capital for serving as a senior advisory board member, and Doris Duke Foundation for serving as a trustee; consulting fees from Infectious Diseases Society of America; nonfinancial support from The Carter Center for serving on the board of directors; and serving as the Bayer Fellow in Health and Technology at the American Academy in Berlin (Bayer does not make vaccine products for infants available in the US), all outside the submitted work. No other disclosures were reported.Additional Information: Dr Walensky served as Director of the CDC from 2021 to 2023.

Even so, acute HBV infection among infants and young children has declined to exceptionally low levels. 
Perinatal infections arise through 3 main pathways (Figure). First, some women with a true positive HBsAg test result do not receive guideline-concordant management or timely immunoprophylaxis of their infant because of systemic, logistical, or access failures (dark blue bars). Second, some mothers do not receive HBsAg screening during pregnancy so their HBV status is unknown (light blue bars). Although guidelines recommend vaccinating these infants, only about 80% of these infants receive this recommended vaccine.9 Finally, some mothers test negative during pregnancy but have HBV infection at delivery, either because of a false-negative result or because they acquire acute HBV while pregnant but after the screening test (orange bars). Infants in this last group would lose protection under a revised policy to remove the birth dose for infants born to mothers with an HBsAg-negative result. 

Figure.  Estimated Number of Perinatal HBV Infections Annually in the US Under Various Hepatitis B Birth Dose Recommendations View LargeDownload   (opens in new tab)Go to Figure in ArticleThe figure represents the subset of mothers with acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. All estimates were calculated using the following default values: 3 591 328 annual births in the US; 0.38% prevalence of HBV infection in pregnant women; 85.4% HBsAg screening in pregnancy; 2% HBsAg false-negative rate (1 − sensitivity); 35.7% perinatal transmission rate of HBV in the absence of vaccine or hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG); and 94% vaccine effectiveness for hepatitis B vaccine birth dose + HBIG, 75% vaccine effectiveness for hepatitis B vaccine birth dose alone.4 Among HBsAg-positive women, 96% of infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers receive HBIG plus vaccination at birth; 3% receive neither vaccine nor HBIG. Among women with false HBsAg-negative and HBsAg-unknown status, 80% receive the vaccine at childbirth.9 HBsAg-negative accounts for false-negative HBsAg results during pregnancy and newly acquired HBV infection after a prior negative HBsAg result. 
Under the current standard of care (universal hepatitis B birth dose), we project 625 perinatal HBV infections annually.5  Eliminating the birth dose for infants of HBsAg-negative mothers—as proposed—would raise the number of cases to 674, an 8% increase (Figure, red circle). Restricting the birth dose only to infants born to HBsAg-positive mothers would raise perinatal HBV cases to 1101—an additional 63%, or a 76% increase from current (Figure, red box). Our projected transmissions are higher than those reported to the CDC, figures known to underestimate the true burden of disease due to underreporting, undiagnosed infections, and possible model bias.5,10 Still, the model is useful for assessing how changes to birth dose recommendations affect expected perinatal transmission. The model likely underestimates the increase that would follow abandonment of universal birth dose policy because it does not account for rising vaccine hesitancy, the birth dose’s protection against postnatal HBV transmission in infancy, or reduced adherence when the first dose is delayed until 1 month of age. 
We applaud the periodic revisiting of routine recommendations as new data emerge and with changes in the epidemiology of disease. In that context, updated studies on the hepatitis B birth dose strengthen prior findings of its remarkable safety and impressive efficacy, documenting a profound decline in HBV infections among infants and children in the US. Delaying the first hepatitis B vaccine dose beyond the newborn period introduces risks that have lifelong detrimental consequences and no measurable health benefit. Universal birth dose recommendations provide a critical safety net for infants and remain a cornerstone of the US strategy to eliminate hepatitis B.

record.text:
E. faecium BSIs in Indian trauma ICU: 97 cases, 51.5% in trauma ICU. 92.5% ampicillin-resistant, 37.6% VRE. Mortality 30.9% (14d), 48.4% final. Early catheter removal 45.3%. 🚑⚠️

#idsky

external.description: Enterococcus faecium drives healthcare-associated bloodstream infections (BSIs) globally, with multidrug resistance and high mortality posing challenges, particularly in trauma settings. Scarce data from Indian trauma centres necessitate analysis to guide management.ObjectivesTo assess the epidemiology, clinical characteristics, antimicrobial resistance and outcomes of E. faecium BSIs in a tertiary trauma care facility in India.MethodsA retrospective study analysed all E. faecium BSI cases in ICUs of a public-sector tertiary trauma centre. Demographic, clinical, microbiological and antimicrobial susceptibility data were collected. BSIs were classified as primary (central line-associated bloodstream infections [CLABSI] or non-CLABSI) or secondary per CDC definitions. Outcomes were evaluated at 14 days and final follow-up using R software.ResultsOf 97 BSI events involving 112 E. faecium isolates, 51.5% occurred in the trauma ICU. Median patient age was 40 years (IQR: 27–55), with 75.3% male. Median time to infection was 8 days (IQR: 5–12) post-admission. CLABSIs, primarily associated with non-tunnelled jugular lines (81.4%), accounted for most cases, followed by non-CLABSI (12.4%) and secondary BSIs (6.2%). Median ICU stay was 21 days (IQR: 14–30). Antimicrobial resistance showed 92.5% of isolates resistant to ampicillin and 37.6% non-susceptible to vancomycin. Linezolid susceptibility was 86.8% and tigecycline susceptibility was 100%. Mortality was 30.9% at 14 days and 48.4% at final follow-up. Early catheter removal occurred in 45.3% of CLABSI cases.DiscussionThe predominance of CLABSIs (81.4%) aligns with global data, where E. faecium is a leading ICU pathogen, driven by catheter use, as seen in European and North American studies. High vancomycin resistance (37.6%) mirrors Indian (up to 81% in high-risk settings) and global (34–81%) VREfm trends, limiting therapeutic options. Linezolid and tigecycline’s efficacy is consistent with international meta-analyses but risks emerging resistance with overuse. Prolonged LOS (21 days) and high mortality (48.4%) reflect VREfm severity, comparable to Chinese (24%) and Italian (27.5–36.6%) studies. Early catheter removal, effective in North American studies, occurred in only 45.3% of CLABSI cases, suggesting underutilization in resource-constrained settings. These findings underscore the need for enhanced catheter care protocols and antimicrobial stewardship to curb MDR E. faecium. Future research should explore molecular resistance mechanisms and cost-effective interventions tailored to Indian trauma settings.ConclusionsE. faecium BSIs in Indian trauma ICUs require urgent infection control and stewardship to address high resistance and mortality.
external.title: P52 Clinical, microbiological and outcome profile of Enterococcus faecium bloodstream infections in a tertiary care trauma centre in India

record.text:
Four LLMs classified 7,239 meds as antimicrobial/non-: Gemini 99.6%✨, Claude 99.4%✨, ChatGPT 81%, Copilot 79.7%. Top models aid stewardship; human check needed.⌛

#idsky

external.description:
View 
abstract



Objective:To evaluate the ability of large language models (LLMs) with targeted feedback to classify medications as antimicrobial or non-antimicrobial and their implication in antimicrobial stewardship.Design:Cross-sectional evaluation using a two-phase process: initial unguided classification and feedback-informed reclassification.Setting:Medication-level analysis of health system prescribing data.Participants:A data set of 7,239 unique medication entries from health systems in the Collaboration to Harmonize Antimicrobial Registry Measures (CHARM) project.Methods:Four LLMs, including ChatGPT-3.5, Copilot GPT-4o, Claude Sonnet 4, and Gemini 2.5 Flash, classified all entries against a manual reference standard. Models then received feedback on 20% of misclassified cases for reclassification. Metrics included accuracy, macro F1-score (95% confidence intervals via bootstrap resampling), positive predictive value, negative predictive value, processing time, and error reduction rates (ERRs). McNemar’s test assessed accuracy between phases and model differences.Results:Baseline accuracy varied among LLMs. Postfeedback, all accuracies improved significantly (P < .001) to Gemini (99.6%), Claude Sonnet 4 (99.4%), ChatGPT-3.5 (81.0%), and Copilot (79.7%). Gemini achieved the highest macro-F1 (98.9%, 95% CI: 98.4–99.3) and ERR (69.2%). Processing time were fastest for Copilot (42 s), followed by ChatGPT-3.5 (47 s), Gemini (1,080 s), and Claude (3,475 s). Manual classification of this task is estimated to take 18 hours without LLM. Misclassification was most common among antiseptics, antiparasitics, and drugs with antimicrobial components for non-infectious uses (eg, sulfasalazine).Conclusions:Top-performing LLMs achieved accuracy levels suitable for automating initial antimicrobial classification in stewardship workflows. Performance variability underscores the need for careful selection and continued human oversight in clinical applications.Summary:Four LLMs were evaluated for antimicrobial classification using 7,239 medications. Claude Sonnet 4 and Gemini achieved>99% accuracy, while ChatGPT-3.5 and Copilot showed substantial limitations. Top performers could automate stewardship workflows with appropriate oversight.
external.title: Evaluation of large language models for antimicrobial classification: implications for antimicrobial stewardship programs

record.text:
I use AI daily in software development and value it. But it's still a tool that has its limits. 

And nothing replaces the knowledge humans create and share ✍️.

Nouveau sketchnote de l’Apéroweb Nancy sur une conf de Jonathan Petitcolas : “You Shouldn’t Write Code Anymore”
De Copilot à Claude Code, l’IA transforme notre façon de coder. Impact en productivité, qualité de code, et vitesse de livraison.
Le dev augmenté est une réalité !
#ClaudeCode #AI

images.alt: Sketchnote illustrée de la conférence “You Shouldn’t Write Code Anymore” présentée par Jonathan Petitcolas lors de l’Apéroweb Nancy du 27 novembre. Le visuel présente un bandeau orange en haut avec le titre en noir et blanc, et une frise chronologique montrant l’évolution des outils d’IA pour le code : 2023 Copilot (autocomplétion++ avec des couacs), 2024 Vibe Coding (prototypage, doc-lift, AI-IDE), 2025 Claude Code (AI Engineering CLI). Le contenu est divisé en deux grandes sections sur fond blanc. À gauche, “Productivité” avec un graphique orange et un trophée jaune doré au centre, détaillant l’Engineering Impact (plus de tickets traités) et le Business Impact (livraison plus rapide), ainsi que la Code Quality (Code Rabbit pour revue de code, Code Fight pour sécurité). Un bandeau bleu en bas annonce “x3 à x5 en productivité”. À droite, “Astuces” avec une ampoule jaune, listant 4 niveaux de pensée avec un cerveau orange, l’Ultra Think Hard Prompt, l’usage des LLM via MCP avec schéma technique (APIs, Docs, Tickets), le Plan Mode (réflexion), l’Edit Mode (modification) avec engrenage, et le mode Parallèle (subagent, multiclone, git worktree, mode headless). Un triangle jaune d’avertissement rappelle d’itérer ses prompts, découper le contexte en tickets, et estimer par IA.

『リミットゼロ ブレイカーズ』新キービジュアルとMAPPA制作ティザー映像が初公開 - AIゲームまとめ

▼詳細はこちら

external.description:
NCSOFTが開発中のアニメーションアクションRPG『リミットゼロ ブレイカーズ』は、新たなキービジュアルとオープニングティザー映像を公開しました。新たなビジュアルでは、主要キャラクター「カイト」、「シオン」、「リズ」が潜空艇「ウィーバーウェル」に乗り込んで航海が始まるシーンが描かれ、物語の始まりを感じさせます。

さらに、アニメーションスタジオ「MAPPA」によるオープニングティザー映像も披露され、主人公「カイト」の覚悟と戦闘シーンが2Dアニメーションで表現されています。映像のフルバージョンは後日公開予定です。

また、映像公開を記念したSNSキャンペーンも開催されており、公式Xでのフォロー＆リポストでキャラクターカードが抽選で当たります。『リミットゼロ ブレイカーズ』は、2026年に配信予定で、iOS、Android、PCに対応、基本プレイは無料のアイテム課金制です。

external.description:
Qookka Gamesは、コーエーテクモゲームスの『信長の野望・新生』公式ライセンスを取得し、スマートフォン向け歴史シミュレーションゲーム『信長の野望 真戦』を2025年12月19日に正式リリースすることを発表しました。

さらに、12月18日より事前ダウンロードを開始し、俳優・北村一輝が本作のイメージキャラクターに就任したことも公開されました。北村は特別映像にも登場予定です。

また、事前登録者数が40万人を突破し、豪華報酬として「武将装備道具【へし切長谷部】」をプレイヤー全員に配布予定です。事前登録者には「登用状×5」や、PS5 Pro、Switch2などの豪華賞品が当たるチャンスも提供されます。

『信長の野望 真戦』は戦国時代を舞台にしたSLG×RPGの新作で、プレイヤーは天下統一を目指して歴史を進めていきます。

If instead your point was: we already have source criticism for primary texts distortions, like Coles Notes, so we can just use that apparatus for AI: respectfully I disagree. It's a (already widely adopted in some fashion or other) different kind of thing and we must engage with that differentness.

I'm not saying such discussions need inevitably to lead to historiographic adoption of AI tools, but right now what we have is more like opposing political factions than careful evaluative frameworks. The frameworks we do have are mostly borrowed from other disciplines, not developed by historians.

We need to have some frank discussions about how to critically engage with AI-supported evidence (even if it's: refuse!) that involve systematic evaluation of outputs, biases, etc., much in the same way we've had these discussions with types of sources and archival/contextual apparatuses.

因みに投稿直後の抽選と60分後の再抽選で漏れて伸びなくても数時間後（体感では6-12時間後）のアルゴリズム再判定による抽選でピックアップされて伸びることもあるようです。その為にはクソ長いテキスト（超短編小説やポエムや制作ノウハウなど絵に則した文脈のもの）を絵と一緒に書いておくと良いようですよ！

これはオーディエンスが読むのに時間かかる＝プラットフォーム滞留時間が伸びる＝広告表示も結果的に増える＝内容のあるテキストと判定されてFor youに載る抽選に通りやすいからだとGrok君とGPT君が解説してくれました。ホントにF⚪︎ckな仕組みですね！

んでまあ、こういう💩仕様である以上、投稿して1-3分内で反応してもらってオススメタブに自分の投稿を載せるにはユーザー動態の多い時間帯（12:00,18-19:00辺り）に投下するのが最適行動となる訳ですが、そうなると同じ時間帯に投稿する人が殺到するので競争が激化して結果的に埋もれる構造になりやすい訳です。
加えて初見で反応してもらうにはセンシティブギリギリな絵の方が注目されやすいので攻めた結果、ラベルや除外も発生しやすくなる→除外連発でデブースティングやシャドウバン喰らってドツボになる訳で、まったくもって💩すぎるXの仕組みなのでありました

record.text: Mad cos bad. Skill issue

I signed up with a data removal service last year (Optery) and strongly urge everyone to consider the same. Data broker sites are like weeds. It's more than a full time job to manage it yourself. I still occasionally send manual requests but Optery's automation does 95% of the work.

The comments are full of people talking about how this is because of DOGE. Folks, it's not. If you do a quick search for your name you are going to find this stuff. Grok is making it a little easier to locate but it is not difficult even without it.

2017年9月某日
俺の背後、気配ひとつ。
入ってきたのは、いかにも通い慣れた風の兄さん一名。
夜の終わり、宇ち多゛は静かにしぼんでいく。
気づけば鍋前、残るは俺を含めてわずか3人。
焼き台の熱も、梅の余韻も、だんだんと遠のいていく。
この“終電前の静寂”みたいな時間がたまらない。
宇ち多゛が一日を閉じる音を、五感で味わった。

鍋前着席。今日はハツナマって決めてた。
でも──まさかのタイミング。席に着いた瞬間、ハツ終了。
「まじか…」と口に出す余裕もなく、ただ呆然。
けど、これが宇ち多゛。仕方ない、こういうもんだ。
未練はあれど、粛々とタンナマに切り替える。
タンナマも好きだし、結果オーライ……たぶん。
今日はそういう日だったんだろう。
ハツよ、また次、会おう。

Het hoofdredactioneel commentaar van @trouw.nl gaat -in dichtvorm!- op deze pakjesavond over de vraag of volwassenen met Sinterklaas liegen:
“De acteur die daar op een podium staat,
en roept: 'Pas op, ik ben een piraat!,
is die de boel aan het bedriegen?
Nee, want acteren is iets anders dan liegen.”

images.alt:
Hoofdredactioneel commentaar van dagblad Trouw:

Een samenleving die niet meer speelt, is een samenleving die zich stierlijk verveelt
Je denkt dat tradities in een vitrine horen
maar nee! Dan zijn ze betekenisloze folklore.
Gelukkig zijn de discussies dus niet verstikt ook nu Zwarte Piet het land is uitgekickt.
(Overigens wel fijn dat dát gevecht
nu dan eindelijk is beslecht!)
Sinterklaas stond dus toch weer garant 
voor polemisch geraas op tv en in de krant.
De lucht ging dit seizoen vooral zinderen
van de vraag: mag je liegen tegen kinderen?
Moet je ze fabeltjes op de mouw spelden over beroetveegde en bemijterde helden?
Wat doen we die tere kinderzieltjes aan
Als ze later ontdekken dat die niet bestaan?
In deze discussie speelt een misverstand
dat zich het beste laat uitleggen aan de hand van een vrij simpele vergelijking:
is kindertheater soms ook geen verrijking?
De acteur die daar op een podium staat, en roept: 'Pas op, ik ben een piraat!, is die de boel aan het bedriegen?
Nee, want acteren is iets anders dan liegen.

Dus oordeel ook over dit feest niet te snel.
Dat is geen bedrog, maar collectief toneelspel.
En een samenleving die niet meer speelt
is een samenleving die zich stierlijk verveelt.
Maar ook mensen die dat accepteren
hadden dit jaar nog iets te jeremiëren.
Dit theaterstuk, zo zeggen zij, lijdt beslist onder een veel te dominante scenarist.
Het Sinterklaasjournaal, zo wordt beweerd heeft de Sintbeleving gemonopoliseerd
Misschien is voor die bedenking iets te zeggen,
maar dan moet je je daar niet bij neerleggen.
Het levend houden van een traditie
is niet iets voor mensen zonder ambitie
Je kunt veel bereiken, als je weigert te buigen
daarvan kan Jerry Afriyie getuigen.
Moeite doen, dat is het geheime recept
ook in het klein, voor de mensen die je liefhebt.
Dus maak een surprise, al ben je geen knutselgenie
en dicht helemaal zelf, zonder ChatGPT!

record.text:
Analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco: nessuna conferma da tracce genetiche sotto unghie Chiara

La nuove analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco non offrono certezze sulle tracce trovate sotto le unghie di Chiara Poggi: risultati non consolidati e ipotesi contrastanti La recente analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco,…

external.description: La nuove analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco non offrono certezze sulle tracce trovate sotto le unghie di Chiara Poggi: risultati non consolidati e ipotesi contrastanti La recente analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco, depositata nell’ambito dell’incidente probatorio, non scioglie i dubbi sul delitto di Chiara Poggi e riapre lo scontro tra difesa e accusa. La genetista Denise Albani conferma che la traccia rinvenuta sulle unghie della vittima mostra un profilo compatibile con la linea paterna di Andrea Sempio, ma sottolinea che il risultato non ha validità scientifica sufficiente per offrire certezze.
external.title: Analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco: nessuna conferma da tracce genetiche sotto unghie Chiara

external.description: La nuove analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco non offrono certezze sulle tracce trovate sotto le unghie di Chiara Poggi: risultati non consolidati e ipotesi contrastanti La recente analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco, depositata nell’ambito dell’incidente probatorio, non scioglie i dubbi sul delitto di Chiara Poggi e riapre lo scontro tra difesa e accusa. La genetista Denise Albani conferma che la traccia rinvenuta sulle unghie della vittima mostra un profilo compatibile con la linea paterna di Andrea Sempio, ma sottolinea che il risultato non ha validità scientifica sufficiente per offrire certezze.
external.title: Analisi Dna sul caso Garlasco: nessuna conferma da tracce genetiche sotto unghie Chiara
